And yes, as you probably could have guessed by this moment, I have decided in 2020, to run for President.

Taylor Swift arrived early to Paul McCartney‚Äôs London office in October, ‚Äúmask on, brimming with excitement.‚Äù ‚ÄúI mostly work from home these days,‚Äù she writes about that day, ‚Äúand today feels like a rare school field trip that you actually want to go on.‚Äù

Swift showed up without a team, doing her own hair and makeup. In addition to being two of the most famous pop songwriters in the world, Swift and McCartney have spent the past year on similar journeys. McCartney, isolated at home in the U.K., recorded McCartney III. Like his first solo album, in 1970, he played nearly all of the instruments himself, resulting in some of his most wildly ambitious songs in a long time. Swift also took some new chances, writing over email with the National‚Äôs Aaron Dessner and recording the raw folklore, which abandons arena pop entirely in favor of rich character songs. It‚Äôs the bestselling album of 2020.

Swift listened to McCartney III as she prepared for today‚Äôs conversation; McCartney delved into folkore. Before the photo shoot, Swift caught up with his daughters Mary (who would be photographing them) and Stella (who designed Swift‚Äôs clothes; the two are close friends). ‚ÄúI‚Äôve met Paul a few times, mostly onstage at parties, but we‚Äôll get to that later,‚Äù Swift writes. ‚ÄúSoon he walks in with his wife, Nancy. They‚Äôre a sunny and playful pair, and I immediately feel like this will be a good day. During the shoot, Paul dances and takes almost none of it too seriously and sings along to Motown songs playing from the speakers. A few times Mary scolds, ‚ÄòDaaad, try to stand still!‚Äô And it feels like a window into a pretty awesome family dynamic. We walk into his office for a chat, and after I make a nervous request, Paul is kind enough to handwrite my favorite lyric of his and sign it. He makes a joke about me selling it, and I laugh because it‚Äôs something I know I‚Äôll cherish for the rest of my life. That‚Äôs around the time when we start talking about music.‚Äù

Taylor Swift: I think it‚Äôs important to note that if this year had gone the way that we thought it was going to go, you and I would have played Glastonbury this year, and instead, you and I both made albums in isolation.

Paul McCartney: Yeah!

Swift: And I remember thinking it would have been so much fun because the times that I‚Äôve run into you, I correlate with being some of the most fun nights of my life. I was at a party with you, when everybody just started playing music. And it was Dave Grohl playing, and you‚Ä¶

McCartney: You were playing one of his songs, weren‚Äôt you?

Swift: Yes, I was playing his song called ‚ÄúBest of You,‚Äù but I was playing it on piano, and he didn‚Äôt recognize it until about halfway through. I just remember thinking, ‚ÄúAre you the catalyst for the most fun times ever?‚Äù Is it your willingness to get up and play music that makes everyone feel like this is a thing that can happen tonight?

McCartney: I mean, I think it‚Äôs a bit of everything, isn‚Äôt it? I‚Äôll tell you who was very ‚Ä¶ Reese Witherspoon was like, ‚ÄúAre you going to sing?‚Äù I said ‚ÄúOh, I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù She said, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got to, yeah!‚Äù She‚Äôs bossing me around. So I said, ‚ÄúWhoa,‚Äù so it‚Äôs a bit of that.

Swift: I love that person, because the party does not turn musical without that person.

McCartney: Yeah, that‚Äôs true.

Swift: If nobody says, ‚ÄúCan you guys play music?‚Äù we‚Äôre not going to invite ourselves up onstage at whatever living-room party it is.

McCartney: I seem to remember Woody Harrelson got on the piano, and he starts playing ‚ÄúLet It Be,‚Äù and I‚Äôm thinking, ‚ÄúI can do that better.‚Äù So I said, ‚ÄúCome on, move over, Woody.‚Äù So we‚Äôre both playing it. It was really nice.‚Ä¶ I love people like Dan Aykroyd, who‚Äôs just full of energy and he loves his music so much, but he‚Äôs not necessarily a musician, but he just wanders around the room, just saying, ‚ÄúYou got to get up, got to get up, do some stuff.‚Äù
Swift: I listened to your new record. And I loved a lot of things about it, but it really did feel like kind of a flex to write, produce, and play every instrument on every track. To me, that‚Äôs like flexing a muscle and saying, ‚ÄúI can do all this on my own if I have to.‚Äù

McCartney: Well, I don‚Äôt think like that, I must admit. I just picked up some of these instruments over the years. We had a piano at home that my dad played, so I picked around on that. I wrote the melody to ‚ÄúWhen I‚Äôm 64‚Äù when I was, you know, a teenager.

Swift: Wow.

McCartney: When the Beatles went to Hamburg, there were always drum kits knocking around, so when there was a quiet moment, I‚Äôd say, ‚ÄúDo you mind if I have a knock around?‚Äù So I was able to practice, you know, without practicing. That‚Äôs why I play right-handed. Guitar was just the first instrument I got. Guitar turned to bass; it also turned into ukulele, mandolin. Suddenly, it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúWow,‚Äù but it‚Äôs really only two or three instruments.

Swift: Well, I think that‚Äôs downplaying it a little bit. In my mind, it came with a visual of you being in the country, kind of absorbing the sort of do-it-yourself [quality] that has had to come with the quarantine and this pandemic. I found that I‚Äôve adapted a do-it-yourself mentality to a lot of things in my career that I used to outsource.  I‚Äôm just wondering what a day of recording in the pandemic looked like for you.

McCartney: Well, I‚Äôm very lucky because I have a studio that‚Äôs, like, 20 minutes away from where I live. We were in lockdown on a farm, a sheep farm with my daughter Mary and her four kids and her husband. So I had four of my grandkids, I had Mary, who‚Äôs a great cook, so I would just drive myself to the studio. And there were two other guys that could come in and we‚Äôd be very careful and distanced and everything: my engineer Steve, and then my equipment guy Keith. So the three of us made the record, and I just started off. I had to do a little bit of film music ‚Äî I had to do an instrumental for a film thing ‚Äî so I did that. And I just kept going, and that turned into the opening track on the album. I would just come in, say, ‚ÄúOh, yeah, what are we gonna do?‚Äù [Then] have some sort of idea, and start doing it. Normally, I‚Äôd start with the instrument I wrote it on, either piano or guitar, and then probably add some drums and then a bit of bass till it started to sound like a record, and then just gradually layer it all up. It was fun. What about yours? You‚Äôre playing guitar and piano on yours.

Swift: Yeah, on some of it, but a lot of it was made with Aaron Dessner, who‚Äôs in a band called the National that I really love. And I had met him at a concert a year before, and I had a conversation with him, asking him how he writes. It‚Äôs my favorite thing to ask people who I‚Äôm a fan of. And he had an interesting answer. He said, ‚ÄúAll the band members live in different parts of the world. So I make tracks. And I send them to our lead singer, Matt, and he writes the top line.‚Äù I just remember thinking, ‚ÄúThat is really efficient.‚Äù And I kind of stored it in my brain as a future idea for a project. You know, how you have these ideas‚Ä¶‚Äâ‚ÄúMaybe one day I‚Äôll do this.‚Äù I always had in my head: ‚ÄúMaybe one day I‚Äôll work with Aaron Dessner.‚Äù

So when lockdown happened, I was in L.A., and we kind of got stuck there. It‚Äôs not a terrible place to be stuck. We were there for four months maybe, and during that time, I sent an email to Aaron Dessner and I said, ‚ÄúDo you think you would want to work during this time? Because my brain is all scrambled, and I need to make something, even if we‚Äôre just kind of making songs that we don‚Äôt know what will happen‚Ä¶‚Äù

McCartney: Yeah, that was the thing. You could do stuff ‚Äî you didn‚Äôt really worry it was going to turn into anything.

Swift: Yeah, and it turned out he had been writing instrumental tracks to keep from absolutely going crazy during the pandemic as well, so he sends me this file of probably 30 instrumentals, and the first one I opened ended up being a song called ‚ÄúCardigan,‚Äù and it really happened rapid-fire like that. He‚Äôd send me a track; he‚Äôd make new tracks, add to the folder; I would write the entire top line for a song, and he wouldn‚Äôt know what the song would be about, what it was going to be called, where I was going to put the chorus. I had originally thought, ‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôll make an album in the next year, and put it out in January or something,‚Äù but it ended up being done and we put it out in July. And I just thought there are no rules anymore, because I used to put all these parameters on myself, like, ‚ÄúHow will this song sound in a stadium? How will this song sound on radio?‚Äù If you take away all the parameters, what do you make? And I guess the answer is folklore.

McCartney: And it‚Äôs more music for yourself than music that‚Äôs got to go do a job. My thing was similar to that: After having done this little bit of film music, I had a lot of stuff that I had been working on, but I‚Äôd said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just going home now,‚Äù and it‚Äôd be left half-finished. So I just started saying, ‚ÄúWell, what about that? I never finished that.‚Äù So we‚Äôd pull it out, and we said, ‚ÄúOh, well, this could be good.‚Äù And because it didn‚Äôt have to amount to anything, I would say, ‚ÄúAh, I really want to do tape loops. I don‚Äôt care if they fit on this song, I just want to do some.‚Äù So I go and make some tape loops, and put them in the song, just really trying to do stuff that I fancy.

I had no idea it would end up as an album; I may have been a bit less indulgent, but if a track was eight minutes long, to tell you the truth, what I thought was, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be taking it home tonight, Mary will be cooking, the grandkids will all be there running around, and someone, maybe Simon, Mary‚Äôs husband, is going to say, ‚ÄòWhat did you do today?‚Äô And I‚Äôm going to go, ‚ÄòOh,‚Äô and then get my phone and play it for them.‚Äù So this became the ritual.

Swift: That‚Äôs the coziest thing I‚Äôve ever heard.
McCartney: Well, it‚Äôs like eight minutes long, and I said, ‚ÄúI hate it when I‚Äôm playing someone something and it finishes after three minutes.‚Äù I kind of like that it just [continues] on.

Swift: You want to stay in the zone.

McCartney: It just keeps going on. I would just come home, ‚ÄúWell, what did you do today?‚Äù ‚ÄúOh, well, I did this. I‚Äôm halfway through this,‚Äù or, ‚ÄúWe finished this.‚Äù

Swift: I was wondering about the numerology element to McCartney III. McCartney I, II, and III have all come out on years with zeroes.

McCartney: Ends of decades.

Swift: Was that important?

McCartney: Yeah, well, this was being done in 2020, and I didn‚Äôt really think about it. I think everyone expected great things of 2020. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gonna be great! Look at that number! 2020! Auspicious!‚Äù Then suddenly Covid hit, and it was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs gonna be auspicious all right, but maybe for the wrong reasons.‚Äù Someone said to me, ‚ÄúWell, you put out McCartney right after the Beatles broke up, and that was 1970, and then you did McCartney II in 1980.‚Äù And I said, ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm going to release this in 2020 just for whatever you call it, the numerology.‚Ä¶‚Äù

Swift: The numerology, the kind of look, the symbolism. I love numbers. Numbers kind of rule my whole world. The numbers 13‚Äâ ‚Ä¶ 89 is a big one. I have a few others that I find‚Ä¶

McCartney: Thirteen is lucky for some.

Swift: Yeah, it‚Äôs lucky for me. It‚Äôs my birthday. It‚Äôs all these weird coincidences of good things that have happened. Now, when I see it places, I look at it as a sign that things are going the way they‚Äôre supposed to. They may not be good now, they could be painful now, but things are on a track. I don‚Äôt know, I love the numerology.

McCartney: It‚Äôs spooky, Taylor. It‚Äôs very spooky. Now wait a minute: Where‚Äôd you get 89?

Swift: That‚Äôs when I was born, in 1989, and so I see it in different places and I just think it‚Äôs‚Ä¶

McCartney: No, it‚Äôs good. I like that, where certain things you attach yourself to, and you get a good feeling off them. I think that‚Äôs great.
Swift: Yeah, one of my favorite artists, Bon Iver, he has this thing with the number 22. But I was also wondering: You have always kind of seeked out a band or a communal atmosphere with like, you know, the Beatles and Wings, and then Egypt Station. I thought it was interesting when I realized you had made a record with no one else. I just wondered, did that feel natural?

McCartney: It‚Äôs one of the things I‚Äôve done. Like with McCartney, because the Beatles had broken up, there was no alternative but to get a drum kit at home, get a guitar, get an amp, get a bass, and just make something for myself. So on that album, which I didn‚Äôt really expect to do very well, I don‚Äôt think it did. But people sort of say, ‚ÄúI like that. It was a very casual album.‚Äù It didn‚Äôt really have to mean anything. So I‚Äôve done that, the play-everything-myself thing. And then I discovered synths and stuff, and sequencers, so I had a few of those at home. I just thought I‚Äôm going to play around with this and record it, so that became McCartney II. But it‚Äôs a thing I do. Certain people can do it. Stevie Wonder can do it. Stevie Winwood, I believe, has done it. So there are certain people quite like that.

When you‚Äôre working with someone else, you have to worry about their variances. Whereas your own variance, you kind of know it. It‚Äôs just something I‚Äôve grown to like. Once you can do it, it becomes a little bit addictive. I actually made some records under the name the Fireman.

Swift: Love a pseudonym.

McCartney: Yeah, for the fun! But, you know, let‚Äôs face it, you crave fame and attention when you‚Äôre young. And I just remembered the other day, I was the guy in the Beatles that would write to journalists and say [speaks in a formal voice]: ‚ÄúWe are a semiprofessional rock combo, and I‚Äôd think you‚Äôd like [us].‚Ä¶ We‚Äôve written over 100 songs (which was a lie), my friend John and I. If you mention us in your newspaper‚Ä¶‚Äù You know, I was always, like, craving the attention.

Swift: The hustle! That‚Äôs so great, though.

McCartney: Well, yeah, you need that.

Swift: Yeah, I think, when a pseudonym comes in is when you still have a love for making the work and you don‚Äôt want the work to become overshadowed by this thing that‚Äôs been built around you, based on what people know about you. And that‚Äôs when it‚Äôs really fun to create fake names and write under them.

McCartney: Do you ever do that?

Swift: Oh, yeah.

McCartney: Oh, yeah? Oh, well, we didn‚Äôt know that! Is that a widely known fact?

Swift: I think it is now, but it wasn‚Äôt. I wrote under the name Nils Sj√∂berg because those are two of the most popular names of Swedish males. I wrote this song called ‚ÄúThis Is What You Came For‚Äù that Rihanna ended up singing. And nobody knew for a while. I remembered always hearing that when Prince wrote ‚ÄúManic Monday,‚Äù they didn‚Äôt reveal it for a couple of months.

McCartney: Yeah, it also proves you can do something without the fame tag. I did something for Peter and Gordon; my girlfriend‚Äôs brother and his mate were in a band called Peter and Gordon. And I used to write under the name Bernard Webb.

Swift: [Laughs.] That‚Äôs a good one! I love it.

McCartney: As Americans call it, Ber-nard Webb. I did the Fireman thing. I worked with a producer, a guy called Youth, who‚Äôs this real cool dude. We got along great. He did a mix for me early on, and we got friendly. I would just go into the studio, and he would say, ‚ÄúHey, what about this groove?‚Äù and he‚Äôd just made me have a little groove going. He‚Äôd say, ‚ÄúYou ought to put some bass on it. Put some drums on it.‚Äù I‚Äôd just spend the whole day putting stuff on it. And we‚Äôd make these tracks, and nobody knew who Fireman was for a while. We must have sold all of 15 copies.

Swift: Thrilling, absolutely thrilling.

McCartney: And we didn‚Äôt mind, you know?

Swift: I think it‚Äôs so cool that you do projects that are just for you. Because I went with my family to see you in concert in 2010 or 2011, and the thing I took away from the show most was that it was the most selfless set list I had ever seen. It was completely geared toward what it would thrill us to hear. It had new stuff, but it had every hit we wanted to hear, every song we‚Äôd ever cried to, every song people had gotten married to, or been brokenhearted to. And I just remembered thinking, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to remember that,‚Äù that you do that set list for your fans.

McCartney: You do that, do you?

Swift: I do now. I think that learning that lesson from you taught me at a really important stage in my career that if people want to hear ‚ÄúLove Story‚Äù and ‚ÄúShake It Off,‚Äù and I‚Äôve played them 300 million times, play them the 300-millionth-and-first time. I think there are times to be selfish in your career, and times to be selfless, and sometimes they line up.

McCartney: I always remembered going to concerts as a kid, completely before the Beatles, and I really hoped they would play the ones I loved. And if they didn‚Äôt, it was kind of disappointing. I had no money, and the family wasn‚Äôt wealthy. So this would be a big deal for me, to save up for months to afford the concert ticket.

Swift: Yeah, it feels like a bond. It feels like that person on the stage has given something, and it makes you as a crowd want to give even more back, in terms of applause, in terms of dedication. And I just remembered feeling that bond in the crowd, and thinking, ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs up there playing these Beatles songs, my dad is crying, my mom is trying to figure out how to work her phone because her hands are shaking so much.‚Äù Because seeing the excitement course through not only me, but my family and the entire crowd in Nashville, it just was really special. I love learning lessons and not having to learn them the hard way. Like learning nice lessons I really value.

McCartney: Well, that‚Äôs great, and I‚Äôm glad that set you on that path. I understand people who don‚Äôt want to do that, and if you do, they‚Äôll say, ‚ÄúOh, it‚Äôs a jukebox show.‚Äù I hear what they‚Äôre saying. But I think it‚Äôs a bit of a cheat, because the people who come to our shows have spent a lot of money. We can afford to go to a couple of shows and it doesn‚Äôt make much difference. But a lot of ordinary working folks‚Äâ‚Ä¶‚Äâit‚Äôs a big event in their life, and so I try and deliver. I also, like you say, try and put in a few weirdos.

Swift: That‚Äôs the best. I want to hear current things, too, to update me on where the artist is. I was wondering about lyrics, and where you were lyrically when you were making this record. Because when I was making folklore, I went lyrically in a total direction of escapism and romanticism. And I wrote songs imagining I was, like, a pioneer woman in a forbidden love affair [laughs]. I was completely‚Äâ‚Ä¶

McCartney: Was this ‚ÄúI want to give you a child‚Äù? Is that one of the lines?

Swift: Oh, that‚Äôs a song called ‚ÄúPeace.‚Äù

McCartney: ‚ÄúPeace,‚Äù I like that one.

Swift: ‚ÄúPeace‚Äù is actually more rooted in my personal life. I know you have done a really excellent job of this in your personal life: carving out a human life within a public life, and how scary that can be when you do fall in love and you meet someone, especially if you‚Äôve met someone who has a very grounded, normal way of living. I, oftentimes, in my anxieties, can control how I am as a person and how normal I act and rationalize things, but I cannot control if there are 20 photographers outside in the bushes and what they do and if they follow our car and if they interrupt our lives. I can‚Äôt control if there‚Äôs going to be a fake weird headline about us in the news tomorrow.

McCartney: So how does that go? Does your partner sympathize with that and understand?

Swift: Oh, absolutely.

McCartney: They have to, don‚Äôt they?

Swift: But I think that in knowing him and being in the relationship I am in now, I have definitely made decisions that have made my life feel more like a real life and less like just a storyline to be commented on in tabloids. Whether that‚Äôs deciding where to live, who to hang out with, when to not take a picture ‚Äî the idea of privacy feels so strange to try to explain, but it‚Äôs really just trying to find bits of normalcy. That‚Äôs what that song ‚ÄúPeace‚Äù is talking about. Like, would it be enough if I could never fully achieve the normalcy that we both crave? Stella always tells me that she had as normal a childhood as she could ever hope for under the circumstances.

McCartney: Yeah, it was very important to us to try and keep their feet on the ground amongst the craziness.

Swift: She went to a regular school‚Äâ.‚Ä¶

McCartney: Yeah, she did.

Swift: And you would go trick-or-treating with them, wearing masks.

McCartney: All of them did, yeah. It was important, but it worked pretty well, because when they kind of reached adulthood, they would meet other kids who might have gone to private schools, who were a little less grounded.

And they could be the budding mothers to [kids]. I remember Mary had a friend, Orlando. Not Bloom. She used to really counsel him. And it‚Äôs ‚Äôcause she‚Äôd gone through that. Obviously, they got made fun of, my kids. They‚Äôd come in the classroom and somebody would sing, ‚ÄúNa na na na,‚Äù you know, one of the songs. And they‚Äôd have to handle that. They‚Äôd have to front it out.

Swift: Did that give you a lot of anxiety when you had kids, when you felt like all this pressure that‚Äôs been put on me is spilling over onto them, that they didn‚Äôt sign up for it? Was that hard for you?

McCartney: Yeah, a little bit, but it wasn‚Äôt like it is now. You know, we were just living a kind of semi-hippie life, where we withdrew from a lot of stuff. The kids would be doing all the ordinary things, and their school friends would be coming up to the house and having parties, and it was just great. I remember one lovely evening when it was Stella‚Äôs birthday, and she brought a bunch of school kids up. And, you know, they‚Äôd all ignore me. It happens very quickly. At first they‚Äôre like, ‚ÄúOh, yeah, he‚Äôs like a famous guy,‚Äù and then it‚Äôs like [yawns]. I like that. I go in the other room and suddenly I hear this music going on. And one of the kids, his name was Luke, and he‚Äôs doing break dancing.

Swift: Ohhh!

McCartney: He was a really good break dancer, so all the kids are hanging out. That allowed them to be kind of normal with those kids. The other thing is, I don‚Äôt live fancy. I really don‚Äôt. Sometimes it‚Äôs a little bit of an embarrassment, if I‚Äôve got someone coming to visit me, or who I know‚Ä¶

Swift: Cares about that stuff?

McCartney: Who‚Äôs got a nice big house, you know. Quincy Jones came to see me and I‚Äôm, like, making him a veggie burger or something. I‚Äôm doing some cooking. Swift: I think that sounds like a perfect day.

McCartney: But that‚Äôs me. I‚Äôm awkward like that. That‚Äôs my kind of thing. Maybe I should have, like, a big stately home. Maybe I should get a staff. But I think I couldn‚Äôt do that. I‚Äôd be so embarrassed. I‚Äôd want to walk around dressed as I want to walk around, or naked, if I wanted to.

Swift: That can‚Äôt happen in Downton Abbey.

McCartney: [Laughs.] Exactly.

Swift: I remember what I wanted to know about, which is lyrics. Like, when you‚Äôre in this kind of strange, unparalleled time, and you‚Äôre making this record, are lyrics first? Or is it when you get a little melodic idea?

McCartney: It was a bit of both. As it kind of always is with me. There‚Äôs no fixed way. People used to ask me and John, ‚ÄúWell, who does the words, who does the music?‚Äù I used to say, ‚ÄúWe both do both.‚Äù We used to say we don‚Äôt have a formula, and we don‚Äôt want one. Because the minute we get a formula, we should rip it up. I will sometimes, as I did with a couple of songs on this album, sit down at the piano and just start noodling around, and I‚Äôll get a little idea and start to fill that out. So the lyrics ‚Äî for me, it‚Äôs following a trail. I‚Äôll start [sings ‚ÄúFind My Way,‚Äù a song from McCartney III]: ‚ÄúI can find my way. I know my left from right, da da da.‚Äù And I‚Äôll just sort of fill it in. Like, we know this song, and I‚Äôm trying to remember the lyrics. Sometimes I‚Äôll just be inspired by something. I had a little book which was all about the constellations and the stars and the orbits of Venus and.‚Ä¶

Swift: Oh, I know that song ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Kiss of Venus‚Äù?

McCartney: Yeah, ‚ÄúThe Kiss of Venus.‚Äù And I just thought, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a nice phrase.‚Äù So I was actually just taking phrases out of the book, harmonic sounds. And the book is talking about the maths of the universe, and how when things orbit around each other, and if you trace all the patterns, it becomes like a lotus flower.

Swift: Wow.

McCartney: It‚Äôs very magical.

Swift: That is magical. I definitely relate to needing to find magical things in this very not-magical time, needing to read more books and learn to sew, and watch movies that take place hundreds of years ago. In a time where, if you look at the news, you just want to have a panic attack ‚Äî I really relate to the idea that you are thinking about stars and constellations.

McCartney: Did you do that on folklore?

Swift: Yes. I was reading so much more than I ever did, and watching so many more films.

McCartney: What stuff were you reading?

Swift: I was reading, you know, books like Rebecca, by Daphne du Maurier, which I highly recommend, and books that dealt with times past, a world that doesn‚Äôt exist anymore. I was also using words I always wanted to use ‚Äî kind of bigger, flowerier, prettier words, like ‚Äúepiphany,‚Äù in songs. I always thought, ‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôll never track on pop radio,‚Äù but when I was making this record, I thought, ‚ÄúWhat tracks? Nothing makes sense anymore. If there‚Äôs chaos everywhere, why don‚Äôt I just use the damn word I want to use in the song?‚Äù

McCartney: Exactly. So you‚Äôd see the word in a book and think, ‚ÄúI love that word‚Äù?

Swift: Yeah, I have favorite words, like ‚Äúelegies‚Äù and ‚Äúepiphany‚Äù and ‚Äúdivorc√©e,‚Äù and just words that I think sound beautiful, and I have lists and lists of them.

McCartney: How about ‚Äúmarzipan‚Äù?

Swift: Love "marzipan."

McCartney: The other day, I was remembering when we wrote ‚ÄúLucy in the Sky With Diamonds‚Äù: ‚Äúkaleidoscope.‚Äù

Swift: ‚ÄúKaleidoscope‚Äù is one of mine! I have a song on 1989, a song called ‚ÄúWelcome to New York,‚Äù that I put the word ‚Äúkaleidoscope‚Äù in just because I‚Äôm obsessed with the word.

McCartney: I think a love of words is a great thing, particularly if you‚Äôre going to try to write a lyric, and for me, it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúWhat is this going to say to that person?‚Äù I often feel like I‚Äôm writing to someone who is not doing so well. So I‚Äôm trying to write songs that might help. Not in a goody-goody, crusading kind of way, but just thinking there have been so many times in my life when I‚Äôve heard a song and felt so much better. I think that‚Äôs the angle I want, that inspirational thing.

I remember once, a friend of mine from Liverpool, we were teenagers and we were going to a fairground. He was a schoolmate, and we had these jackets that had a little fleck in the material, which was the cool thing at the time.

Swift: We should have done matching jackets for this photo shoot.

McCartney: Find me a fleck, I‚Äôm in. But we went to the fair, and I just remember ‚Äî this is what happens with songs ‚Äî there was this girl at the fair. This is just a little Liverpool fair ‚Äî it was in a place called Sefton Park ‚Äî and there was this girl, who was so beautiful. She wasn‚Äôt a star. She was so beautiful. Everyone was following her, and it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúWow.‚Äù It‚Äôs like a magical scene, you know? But all this gave me a headache, so I ended up going back to his house ‚Äî I didn‚Äôt normally get headaches. And we thought, ‚ÄúWhat can we do?‚Äù So we put on the Elvis song ‚ÄúAll Shook Up.‚Äù By the end of that song, my headache had gone. I thought, you know, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs powerful.‚Äù

Swift: That really is powerful.

McCartney: I love that, when people stop me in the street and say, ‚ÄúOh, I was going through an illness and I listened to a lot of your stuff, and I‚Äôm better now and it got me through,‚Äù or kids will say, ‚ÄúIt got me through exams.‚Äù You know, they‚Äôre studying, they‚Äôre going crazy, but they put your music on. I‚Äôm sure it happens with a lot of your fans. It inspires them, you know?

Swift: Yeah, I definitely think about that as a goal. There‚Äôs so much stress everywhere you turn that I kind of wanted to make an album that felt sort of like a hug, or like your favorite sweater that makes you feel like you want to put it on.

McCartney: What, a ‚Äúcardigan‚Äù?

Swift: Like a good cardigan, a good, worn-in cardigan. Or something that makes you reminisce on your childhood. I think sadness can be cozy. It can obviously be traumatic and stressful, too, but I kind of was trying to lean into sadness that feels like somehow enveloping in not such a scary way ‚Äî like nostalgia and whimsy incorporated into a feeling like you‚Äôre not all right. Because I don‚Äôt think anybody was really feeling like they were in their prime this year. Isolation can mean escaping into your imagination in a way that‚Äôs kind of nice.

McCartney: I think a lot of people have found that. I would say to people, ‚ÄúI feel a bit guilty about saying I‚Äôm actually enjoying this quarantine thing,‚Äù and people go, ‚ÄúYeah, I know, don‚Äôt say it to anyone.‚Äù A lot of people are really suffering.

Swift: Because there‚Äôs a lot in life that‚Äôs arbitrary. Completely and totally arbitrary. And [the quarantine] is really shining a light on that, and also a lot of things we have that we outsource that you can actually do yourself.

McCartney: I love that. This is why I said I live simply. That‚Äôs, like, at the core of it. With so many things, something goes wrong and you go, ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôll get somebody to fix that.‚Äù And then it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúNo, let me have a look at it.‚Ä¶‚Äù

Swift: Get a hammer and a nail.

McCartney: ‚ÄúMaybe I can put that picture up.‚Äù It‚Äôs not rocket science. The period after the Beatles, when we went to live in Scotland on a really ‚Äî talk about dumpy ‚Äî little farm. I mean, I see pictures of it now and I‚Äôm not ashamed, but I‚Äôm almost ashamed. Because it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúGod, nobody‚Äôs cleaned up around here.‚Äù

But it was really a relief. Because when I was with the Beatles, we‚Äôd formed Apple Records, and if I wanted a Christmas tree, someone would just buy it. And I thought, after a while, ‚ÄúNo, you know what? I really would like to go and buy our Christmas tree. Because that‚Äôs what everyone does.‚Äù So you go down ‚Äî ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have that one‚Äù ‚Äî and you carried it back. I mean, it‚Äôs little, but it‚Äôs huge at the same time.

I needed a table in Scotland and I was looking through a catalog and I thought, ‚ÄúI could make one. I did woodwork in school, so I know what a dovetail joint is.‚Äù So I just figured it out. I‚Äôm just sitting in the kitchen, and I‚Äôm whittling away at this wood and I made this little joint. There was no nail technology ‚Äî it was glue. And I was scared to put it together. I said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to fit,‚Äù but one day, I got my woodwork glue and thought, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no going back.‚Äù But it turned out to be a real nice little table I was very proud of. It was that sense of achievement.

The weird thing was, Stella went up to Scotland recently and I said, ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt it there?‚Äù and she said, ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù Anyway, I searched for it. Nobody remembered it. Somebody said, ‚ÄúWell, there‚Äôs a pile of wood in the corner of one of the barns, maybe that‚Äôs it. Maybe they used it for firewood.‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs not firewood.‚Äù Anyway, we found it, and do you know how joyous that was for me? I was like, ‚ÄúYou found my table?!‚Äù Somebody might say that‚Äôs a bit boring.

Swift: No, it‚Äôs cool!

McCartney: But it was a real sort of great thing for me to be able to do stuff for yourself. You were talking about sewing. I mean normally, in your position, you‚Äôve got any amount of tailors.

Swift: Well, there‚Äôs been a bit of a baby boom recently; several of my friends have gotten pregnant.

McCartney: Oh, yeah, you‚Äôre at the age.

Swift: And I was just thinking, ‚ÄúI really want to spend time with my hands, making something for their children.‚Äù So I made this really cool flying-squirrel stuffed animal that I sent to one of my friends. I sent a teddy bear to another one, and I started making these little silk baby blankets with embroidery. It‚Äôs gotten pretty fancy. And I‚Äôve been painting a lot.

McCartney: What do you paint? Watercolors?

Swift: Acrylic or oil. Whenever I do watercolor, all I paint is flowers. When I have oil, I really like to do landscapes. I always kind of return to painting a lonely little cottage on a hill.

McCartney: It‚Äôs a bit of a romantic dream. I agree with you, though, I think you‚Äôve got to have dreams, particularly this year. You‚Äôve got to have something to escape to. When you say ‚Äúescapism,‚Äù it sounds like a dirty word, but this year, it definitely wasn‚Äôt. And in the books you‚Äôre reading, you‚Äôve gone into that world. That‚Äôs, I think, a great thing. Then you come back out. I normally will read a lot before I go to bed. So I‚Äôll come back out, then I‚Äôll go to sleep, so I think it really is nice to have those dreams that can be fantasies or stuff you want to achieve.

Swift: You‚Äôre creating characters. This was the first album where I ever created characters, or wrote about the life of a real-life person. There‚Äôs a song called ‚Äúthe last great american dynasty‚Äù that‚Äôs about this real-life heiress who lived just an absolutely chaotic, hectic‚Ä¶

McCartney: She‚Äôs a fantasy character?

Swift: She‚Äôs a real person. Who lived in the house that I live in.

McCartney: She‚Äôs a real person? I listened to that and I thought, ‚ÄúWho is this?‚Äù

Swift: Her name was Rebekah Harkness. And she lived in the house that I ended up buying in Rhode Island. That‚Äôs how I learned about her. But she was a woman who was very, very talked about, and everything she did was scandalous. I found a connection in that. But I also was thinking about how you write ‚ÄúEleanor Rigby‚Äù and go into that whole story about what all these people in this town are doing and how their lives intersect, and I hadn‚Äôt really done that in a very long time with my music. It had always been so microscope personal.

McCartney: Yeah, ‚Äôcause you were writing breakup songs like they were going out of style.

Swift: I was, before my luck changed [laughs]. I still write breakup songs. I love a good breakup song. Because somewhere in the world, I always have a friend going through a breakup, and that will make me write one.

McCartney: Yeah, this goes back to this thing of me and John: When you‚Äôve got a formula, break it. I don‚Äôt have a formula. It‚Äôs the mood I‚Äôm in. So I love the idea of writing a character. And, you know, trying to think, ‚ÄúWhat am I basing this on?‚Äù So ‚ÄúEleanor Rigby‚Äù was based on old ladies I knew as a kid. For some reason or other, I got great relationships with a couple of local old ladies. I was thinking the other day, I don‚Äôt know how I met them, it wasn‚Äôt like they were family. I‚Äôd just run into them, and I‚Äôd do their shopping for them.

Swift: That‚Äôs amazing.

McCartney: It just felt good to me. I would sit and talk, and they‚Äôd have amazing stories. That‚Äôs what I liked. They would have stories from the wartime ‚Äî because I was born actually in the war ‚Äî and so these old ladies, they were participating in the war. This one lady I used to sort of just hang out with, she had a crystal radio that I found very magical. In the war, a lot of people made their own radios ‚Äî you‚Äôd make them out of crystals [sings The Twilight Zone theme].

Swift: How did I not know this? That sounds like something I would have tried to learn about.

McCartney: It‚Äôs interesting, because there is a lot of parallels with the virus and lockdowns and wartime. It happened to everyone. Like, this isn‚Äôt HIV, or SARS, or Avian flu, which happened to others, generally. This has happened to everyone, all around the world. That‚Äôs the defining thing about this particular virus. And, you know, my parents ‚Ä¶ it happened to everyone in Britain, including the queen and Churchill. War happened. So they were all part of this thing, and they all had to figure out a way through it. So you figured out folklore. I figured out McCartney III.

Swift: And a lot of people have been baking sourdough bread. Whatever gets you through!

McCartney: Some people used to make radios. And they‚Äôd take a crystal ‚Äî we should look it up, but it actually is a crystal. I thought, ‚ÄúOh, no, they just called it a crystal radio,‚Äù but it‚Äôs actually crystals like we know and love.

Swift: Wow.

McCartney: And somehow they get the radio waves ‚Äî this crystal attracts them ‚Äî they tune it in, and that‚Äôs how they used to get their news. Back to ‚ÄúEleanor Rigby,‚Äù so I would think of her and think of what she‚Äôs doing and then just try to get lyrical, just try to bring poetry into it, words you love, just try to get images like ‚Äúpicks up the rice in the church where a wedding has been,‚Äù and Father McKenzie ‚Äúis darning his socks in the night.‚Äù You know, he‚Äôs a religious man, so I could‚Äôve said, you know, ‚Äúpreparing his Bible,‚Äù which would have been more obvious. But ‚Äúdarning his socks‚Äù kind of says more about him. So you get into this lovely fantasy. And that‚Äôs the magic of songs, you know. It‚Äôs a black hole, and then you start doing this process, and then there‚Äôs this beautiful little flower that you‚Äôve just made. So it is very like embroidery, making something.

Swift: Making a table.

McCartney: Making a table.

Swift: Wow, it would‚Äôve been so fun to play Glastonbury for the 50th anniversary together.

McCartney: It would‚Äôve been great, wouldn‚Äôt it? And I was going to be asking you to play with me.

Swift: Were you going to invite me? I was hoping that you would. I was going to ask you.

McCartney: I would‚Äôve done ‚ÄúShake It Off.‚Äù

Swift: Oh, my God, that would have been amazing.

McCartney: I know it, it‚Äôs in C!

Swift: One thing I just find so cool about you is that you really do seem to have the joy of it, still, just no matter what. You seem to have the purest sense of joy of playing an instrument and making music, and that‚Äôs just the best, I think.

McCartney: Well, we‚Äôre just so lucky, aren‚Äôt we?

Swift: We‚Äôre really lucky.

McCartney: I don‚Äôt know if it ever happens to you, but with me, it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúOh, my god, I‚Äôve ended up as a musician.‚Äù

Swift: Yeah, I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs my job.

McCartney: I must tell you a story I told Mary the other day, which is just one of my favorite little sort of Beatles stories. We were in a terrible, big blizzard, going from London to Liverpool, which we always did. We‚Äôd be working in London and then drive back in the van, just the four of us with our roadie, who would be driving. And this was a blizzard. You couldn‚Äôt see the road. At one point, it slid off and it went down an embankment. So it was ‚ÄúAhhh,‚Äù a bunch of yelling. We ended up at the bottom. It didn‚Äôt flip, luckily, but so there we are, and then it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúOh, how are we going to get back up? We‚Äôre in a van. It‚Äôs snowing, and there‚Äôs no way.‚Äù We‚Äôre all standing around in a little circle, and thinking, ‚ÄúWhat are we going to do?‚Äù And one of us said, ‚ÄúWell, something will happen.‚Äù And I thought that was just the greatest. I love that, that‚Äôs a philosophy.

Swift: ‚ÄúSomething will happen.‚Äù

McCartney: And it did. We sort of went up the bank, we thumbed a lift, we got the lorry driver to take us, and Mal, our roadie, sorted the van and everything. So that was kind of our career. And I suppose that‚Äôs like how I ended up being a musician and a songwriter: ‚ÄúSomething will happen.‚Äù

Swift: That‚Äôs the best.

McCartney: It‚Äôs so stupid it‚Äôs brilliant. It‚Äôs great if you‚Äôre ever in that sort of panic attack: ‚ÄúOh, my God,‚Äù or, ‚ÄúAhhh, what am I going to do?‚Äù

Swift: ‚ÄúSomething will happen.‚Äù

McCartney: All right then, thanks for doing this, and this was, you know, a lot of fun.

Swift: You‚Äôre the best. This was so awesome. Those were some quality stories!

And I could tell you now but never mindTHE PALM TREES ARRIVED IN FEBRUARY, seven in all, set against a pastel blue backdrop with superimposed stars. It appeared that a new Taylor Swift era was upon us ‚Äî that the old happy-go-lucky Taylor was not, in fact, dead. Or did it? It was only an Instagram photo, just one more picture in an infinite content scroll. But it also came from a pop star known for prodigious hint-dropping, whose fans turn every piece of info into an online archaeological dig.

As expected, the summery post sent Swifties sifting through each detail with a fine-tooth comb. What did the trees symbolize? An overdue vacation? A recently purchased beach house? A secret palm-frond collection? Or maybe, as many surmised, it was new music. One Twitter user predicted that the number of stars in the background of the photo hinted at a single drop: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs about 60/61 [stars]Ô∏è. There‚Äôs 61 days until April 26, FRIDAY, a SINGLE RELEASE day!‚Äù Another said it was the unofficial announcement of her next LP: ‚ÄúOkay so in this picture there are 4 palm trees on the left (4 country albums). There are two palm trees on the right (2 pop albums). There is one large palm tree in the middle. This represents her new album.‚Äù These may sound like ludicrous conspiracy theories ‚Äî for the record, they were mostly correct ‚Äî but they fit firmly within the Taylor Swift Musical Universe (it‚Äôs like the Marvel Cinematic Universe but with more guitars and fewer Stan Lee cameos).

‚ÄúI posted that the day that I finished the seventh album,‚Äù says Swift about the photo. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt expect [my fans] to know that. I figured they‚Äôd figure it out later, but a lot of their theories were actually correct. Those Easter eggs were just trying to establish that tone, which I foreshadowed ages ago in a Spotify vertical video for ‚ÄòDelicate‚Äô by painting my nails those [pastel] colors.‚Äù

It‚Äôs now April, and the 29-year-old pop star is in a Los Angeles photo studio, giving her first sit-down magazine interview in three years. She wants to discuss the art of placing hints inside her work, as well as the upcoming record, which she recorded as soon as she finished the Reputation Tour. She‚Äôs also keen on detailing her own obsessions, talking up the TV shows, books, and songs that help shape her outlook on life.

Over the past 13 years, Swift has perfected the pop culture feedback loop: She shares updates about her life and drops hints about new music, which fans then gobble up and re-promote with their own theories, which Swift then re-shares on her Tumblr or incorporates into future clues. It‚Äôs like a T-Swift-built Escher staircase of personal memories and moments that tease what‚Äôs next. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve trained them to be that way,‚Äù she says of her fans‚Äô astute detective work. Swift is a pop culture fanatic herself (see: the jean jacket she‚Äôs wearing on the EW cover) and has an innate understanding of the lengths her audience will go to be a part of the original creation. ‚ÄúI love that they like the cryptic hint-dropping. Because as long as they like it, I‚Äôll keep doing it. It‚Äôs fun. It feels mischievous and playful.‚Äù

Through this approach, Swift has designed the ultimate artistic scavenger hunt ‚Äî and it‚Äôs easy to get swept up in its drama, even if you don‚Äôt listen to her music. Her moments aren‚Äôt always hidden, either. Sometimes Swift highlights aspects of her world just so fans feel like they‚Äôre on the journey with her. Like the time in March 2018 when pop singer Hayley Kiyoko was accused of shading Swift after mentioning her name during an interview. On Tumblr, Swift re-shared a fan‚Äôs post, adding commentary that defended Kiyoko, which immediately dispelled any conflicts between the two artists; Swift‚Äôs post subsequently received more than 29,000 notes. Four months later, she invited Kiyoko on stage during the Reputation Tour to sing her hit ‚ÄúCurious.‚Äù Kiyoko returned the favor when she had Swift join her that December at a benefit on behalf of the LGBTQ organization the Ally Coalition to perform ‚ÄúDelicate.‚Äù Fans of both artists were elated by the mutual support.

The feedback loop also extends outside of music. In October 2018, Swift broke her silence about politics by publicly endorsing two candidates for office in her adopted state of Tennessee, while encouraging her followers to register to vote. She kept up the civic momentum through Election Day when she asked fans to post selfies after voting; Swift then eagerly re-promoted her favorites on Instagram stories.

This practice of sharing and re-sharing and sharing again is why listeners consider Swift one of the world‚Äôs most accessible pop stars, someone willing to not only interact with her audience but invite them to secret listening sessions, or make the occasional surprise visit to their wedding or prom. It‚Äôs a symbiotic relationship, one that, as Swift tells EW, helped her dig out of the darker era of reputation. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs definitely the fans that made that tonal shift in the way I was feeling,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúSongwriters need to communicate, and part of communicating correctly is when you put out a message that is understood the way you meant it. reputation was interesting because I‚Äôd never before had an album that wasn‚Äôt fully understood until it was seen live. When it first came out everyone thought it was just going to be angry; upon listening to the whole thing they realized it‚Äôs actually about love and friendship, and finding out what your priorities are.‚Äù

Then, during the Reputation Tour, she had an epiphany: that despite the caricature that she thought had been created of her, there were many people who saw what others had simply refused to. ‚ÄúI would look out into the audience and I‚Äôd see these amazing, thoughtful, caring, wonderful, empathetic people,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúSo often with our takedown culture, talking s‚Äî about a celebrity is basically the same as talking s‚Äî about the new iPhone. So when I go and I meet fans, I see that they actually see me as a flesh-and-blood human being. That ‚Äî as contrived as it may sound ‚Äî changed [me] completely, assigning humanity to my life.‚Äù

At tour‚Äôs end, she channeled that positive energy into the studio, recording the new album in just under three months. But the fast pace won‚Äôt mean a short LP. Swift confirmed that her seventh record (she hasn‚Äôt announced a title yet; the working nickname among fans is TS7) will include more songs than any of her previous releases. ‚ÄúI try not to go into making an album with any expectation,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI started to write so much that I knew immediately it would probably be bigger.‚Äù

The project will also feature a mix of old and new collaborators (on the candy-coated lead single ‚ÄúME!‚Äù Swift brought in Panic! At the Disco frontman Brendon Urie and coproducer Joel Little, both of whom she had never worked with), but she is unsurprisingly coy about doling out much more information, as if doing so would break the carefully honed T-Swiftian feedback loop. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of a lot on this album,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to convey an emotional spectrum. I definitely don‚Äôt wanna have too much of one thing‚Ä¶. You get some joyful songs and you get the bops, as they say.‚Äù There‚Äôs also, she adds, some ‚Äúreally, really, really, really sad songs,‚Äù but ‚Äúnot enough to where you need to worry about me.‚Äù

She gives us one more clue: The true distinction between TS7 and reputation is in the delivery. ‚ÄúThis time around I feel more comfortable being brave enough to be vulnerable, because my fans are brave enough to be vulnerable with me. Once people delve into the album, it‚Äôll become pretty clear that that‚Äôs more of the fingerprint of this ‚Äî that it‚Äôs much more of a singer-songwriter, personal journey than the last one.‚Äù

The past month has seen a deluge of Swift activity, from the release of the new single to dropping more hints in interviews about the record and its title, which is apparently hidden somewhere inside the ‚ÄúME!‚Äù music video (current fan guesses include Kaleidoscope and Daisy). But if the Easter eggs from the pop star seem like a business-as-usual routine, she says this album does indeed mark a new era of her life, where she‚Äôs been better able to prioritize what‚Äôs important to her.
‚ÄúOur priorities can get messed up existing in a society that puts a currency on curating the way people see your life,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúSocial media has given people a way to express their art. I use it to connect with fans. But on the downside you feel like there are 3 trillion new invisible hoops that you have to jump through, and you feel like you‚Äôll never be able to jump through them all correctly. I ‚Äî along with a lot of my friends and fans ‚Äî am trying to figure out how to navigate living my life and not just curating what I want people to think living my life is. I‚Äôm not always able to maintain a balance, and I think that‚Äôs important for everyone to know about. We‚Äôre always learning, and that‚Äôs something that I also had to learn ‚Äî that I‚Äôve got to be brave enough to learn. Learning in public is so humiliating sometimes‚Ä¶. Do I feel more balanced in my life than I ever have before? Um, probably yeah. But is that permanent? No. And I think being okay with that has put me in a bit of a better position.‚Äù Strong words to live by, to quote, to re-share, to tweet back to her, and see if she‚Äôll respond.[Verse 1]

[Journal Snippet]
I‚Äôm getting older and less sure of what you like about me anyway
